item.title: Genshin Impact: Under The Tonatiuh's Wings Achievement
item.description:
Tonatiuh in Genshin Impact is a sky-faring ship built by the Lord of the Cinder City. As a flying ship, it's no wonder that it's located far above the ground, floating between the clouds. After reaching the legendary place, players who try to jump down will find themselves falling for a really long time with nothing but gray clouds in sight. Once the long seconds pass, players will finally start to see the landscape of Natlan, looking small from way up there.

Under the Tonatiuh's Wings is an achievement in Genshin Impact that celebrates what and where Tonatiuh is. The trophy is obtained from an area in the sky, but not anywhere close to how far up Tonatiuh is.

Under The Tonatiuh's Wings Achievement In Genshin Impact

To get the Under the Tonatiuh's Wings achievement in Genshin Impact , head to the two circular platforms on the map northeast of the main Ochkanatlan island. Players can reach the area by gliding down from the high ground of Tonatiuh or flying up with a Qucusaurus.

There are two puzzles to solve, one in the upper-right and another in the bottom-left. Both are a Relay Ball puzzle in Genshin Impact , where the mechanism consists of the following things:

  • Relay Balls that can be grabbed and thrown with a Yumkasaurus ability.
  • A portal-like colored-platform that's the "goal" for the Relay Balls.
  • Ball Path Converters that can change the color of the Relay Ball so that it matches the colored-platform.

Under The Tonatiuh's Wings Puzzle #1 (Upper-Right)

In the first puzzle, throwing the Relay Ball into the Ball Path Converter will cause the Relay Ball to be thrown into the sky, as the goal is not aligned with the Converter. Therefore, players must do the following to solve the riddle:

  • Grab the Relay Ball with a Yumkasaurus ability or characters from the Scions of the Canopy like Kinich in Genshin Impact .
  • Throw the Relay Ball to the Ball Path Converter.
  • Wait until the Ball touches the Converter, then immediately pull the Grappling Hook underneath to rotate the positioning.
  • Watch where the Relay Ball goes and adjust the timing if necessary.

Solving this puzzle will reward players with an Exquisite Chest, and a Phlogiston Wind Current will appear to take Travelers to the second puzzle.

Phlogiston Wind Current will damage characters that aren't from the Flower-Feather Clan or indwelling the Qucusaurus form.

Under The Tonatiuh's Wings Puzzle #2 (Bottom-Left)

The second puzzle is similar to the first but with a small twist, and it rewards a Precious Chest in Genshin Impact . Here's how players can solve it:

  • Pull the Grappling Hook to rotate the Ball Path Converter until one of them is aligned with the goal.
  • Throw the Relay Ball to the Ball Path Converter on the opposite side.
  • As the Relay Ball is flying, use the Grappling Hook to rotate the positioning.
  • Watch as the Relay Ball flies into the goal.

item.title: 8 Scariest Open-World Games
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Open-world games can feature horror elements that create an unnerving experience for players.
  • Games like Days Gone, Dying Light, and Metro Exodus ramp up tension with nightmarish enemies and limited resources.
  • Survival horror titles like Project Zomboid, Pathologic 2, Sons of the Forest, Darkwood, and STALKER offer unique and terrifying experiences.

Most people assume open-world games to be these joyful experiences that fans can't get enough of. While this is true in the majority of cases, some open-world games feature elements of horror that can make these sandboxes feel rather unnerving.

Players must brave the dangers of these open worlds and survive by any means necessary, which is easier said than done. Nightmarish enemies, oppressive environments, and stingy economies are just a few of the many ways that these scary open-world games ramp up the tension.

8 Days Gone

An Underrated Open-World Title Where The Zombie Hordes Can Be A Nightmare

Days Gone had its fair share of problems, but most fans would agree that this open-world game came into its own after a relatively slow beginning. The fact that players don't even encounter a zombie horde until they've invested a few hours into the experience is a testament to this game's slow burn.

The panic players experience when a horde descends on them is immense in the game's early goings, with a lack of resources ensuring that players must either run or succumb to the zombies who are trying to tear them apart. This zombie open-world game may have some rough edges, but it excels at scaring players when everything clicks.

7 Dying Light

A Zombie-Infested World Where Players Use Parkour To Outrun Their Enemies

It's a testament to the scare factor of Dying Light that players will still feel scared out of their wits even if they can run, jump, and climb as much as they want. The days are easier to deal with, but players will be in for a rough time if night rears its ugly head.

The game's Volatiles are nightmarish to deal with and will force players to sprint as fast as possible as these super-powered zombies chase them down. Reaching a safe haven when these Volatiles are mere seconds away from pouncing goes a long way in helping Dying Light stand out as one of the scariest open-world games players can get their hands on.

6 Metro Exodus

A Post-Apocalyptic World That's Overflowing With Unnerving Atmosphere

Fans of the Metro series were understandably worried when news came out that the third game in the series would feature an open world. People wondered if the oppressive and horrifying atmosphere of this franchise would translate well to a sandbox, but all these complaints disappeared upon release.

The open world of Metro Exodus is one of the scariest environments that players can get immersed in, with the hardcore gameplay only adding to the tension. Players will also be elated to find that some of the game's levels take place in linear environments, channeling the immaculate atmosphere of the previous two games.

5 Project Zomboid

A Deep And Engaging Survival Game Where The Threat Of Flesh-Eating Zombies Runs Rampant

Project Zomboid is one of the deepest and most engaging open-world zombie games players can get their hands on. The rudimentary graphics may not seem all that appealing, but players don't know true horror until they invest in their character's stats only for an unrelenting wave of zombies to arrive in a bid to end their run.

Fortifying hideouts, leveling up skills, and scrounging for resources are a huge part of what makes this game such a joy to play. Players will be nervous every single time they have to hunt for supplies, since a single mistake can lead to a wave of zombies tearing the player character apart in no time.

4 Pathologic 2

A Surreal Horror Game That Is Uncomfortable And Yet Alluring

To call Pathologic 2 a sequel would be doing a disservice to this odd open-world title. It's essentially a remake of the first game with some original elements of its own that lets players explore a town suffering from a deadly disease outbreak.

What makes this game so horrifying is its bizarre structure, with surrealism running rampant in every facet. Players will question what's real and what isn't in this psychological horror title, which is one of the weirdest and most unique open-world games fans can check out.

3 Sons Of The Forest

The Sequel To One Of The Best Open-World Survival Horror Games Ever Made

The Forest was a nightmarish experience where players had to survive in the woods while being hounded by bloodthirsty cannibals, and the sequel expands on this concept to make for a bigger, bolder, and more horrifying title than ever before.

Sons of the Forest can be a harrowing experience, and players must ensure that their survival skills are on point to stay alive in these hostile woods. It's important to set up defenses, hoard supplies, and craft weapons if players don't want to succumb to the relentless attacks of a cannibalistic cult.

2 Darkwood

Boasts A Semi-Open World Where Dangers Await Around Every Corner

Even with a top-down perspective, the limited view cone and immaculate atmosphere of Darkwood help it stand out as one of the best indie horror games ever made. Players explore a semi-open world where they find resources to help them survive the night in their hideout against nightmarish monsters.

Darkwood does a masterful job of scaring players out of their wits, forcing them to look over their shoulder with every step they take. It's a nightmarish title with an engrossing story that will compel players to stick around till the very end to uncover the mysteries surrounding the plot.

1 S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow Of Chernobyl

A Hardcore Survival-Horror Game With Tight Resource Management

The STALKER series has become an underrated survival horror franchise that fans of hardcore open-world games will have a great time with. The first game is hailed by many as the best one in the series, making players think twice before picking up a single item or venturing into hostile territory.

Fighting mutated enemies and seeking out any kind of respite after a harrowing encounter is a huge part of what makes the STALKER series so special. The Chernobyl Exclusion Zone is a nightmare to explore, with a single mistake leading to the player's death almost every time.

item.title: Luma Island: How to Unlock Fast Travel
item.description:
Luma Island is a beautiful game where exploration feels extremely rewarding. There are thousands of Treasure Chests and Secrets riddled all over the map. But when you're gathering supplies from a specific region, the long walk back home can get exhausting.

While at first glance, players might think that Luma Island doesn't have any fast travel mechanic in the game, there is a way to travel to different biomes quickly right from your Farm. Since the process isn't explained clearly, players can play through the entire game without unlocking it. In this guide, we'll give you a complete rundown of how the fast travel system works in Luma Island and how you can unlock it.

How To Unlock Fast Travel in Luma Island

To unlock Fast Travel, players must build a Cottage on Luma Island . But before you can build a Cottage, you'll have to find its Blueprint. While most blueprints in the game can be found in the Blueprint Shop in Town, you'll have to go to the Forest biome for this one.

Head to the beach area in the northwestern part of the Forest Zone. You'll see a Golden Chest on an island near a tree. You'll find the Cottage Blueprint inside it. After unlocking the blueprint, you'll find it in the Houses section of your Drawings menu.

Here are the materials you'll need to build the Cottage in Luma Island :

Resource Name

Quantity

How to Get

Clay

50x

Found in treasure chests in the Forest region.

Scaffolding

5x

Bought from Sophia's General Store in Town near the Town Hall.

Forest Plank

100x

Crafted in the Saw Mill using Forest Wood.

Forest Stone Block

100x

Crafted in the Saw Mill using Forest Stone.

Iron Bar

50x

Crafted in the Ore Smelter using Iron Ore and Charcoal.

Glass

25x

Crafted in the Kiln using Sand and Charcoal.

Fiber

25x

Crafted in the Simple Workbench using Reed.

Box of Nails

25x

Found in treasure chests in the Forest Region.

Cottage Permit

1x

Bought from Sophia's General Store.

As you can see, most of the resources required to build the Cottage on Luma Island can be found in the Forest biome. So you'll have to spend quite a while exploring the zone picking up crafting materials. Consider upgrading your Copper Pickaxe and Copper Axe a few times to harvest material faster.

You'll also have to help repair Sophia's General Store to unlock the Scaffolding and Cottage Permit for purchase. The Scaffolding costs 500 Gold for each unit while the Cottage Permit costs 1000 Coins. If you've been progressing through your Professions, Coins shouldn't be a big issue for you at this point.

Check out this guide to learn how to repair the General Store.

Once you have all the crafting ingredients in your inventory, head back to your farm, pick a nice spot, and build the Cottage.

How to Use Fast Travel in Luma Island

Simply building the Cottage isn't enough for players to use fast travel in Luma Island . You'll also have to explore each biome and unlock the fast travel points in them so that you can travel to it from your Farm. If you've explored the Forest region properly while gathering supplies, you should already have the Forest fast travel point unlocked.

The fast travel point resembles a stone archway with stone pillars on both sides.

Head inside the Cottage on your Farm and use the Trapdoor to go to the basement. You'll notice a glowing green portal in one corner of the basement. Walk up and interact with it. Now you can hold the interact button to teleport to the biomes you've unlocked.

Each biome has a fast travel point that you'll have to discover to unlock.

Whether you're hunting down secrets like the Tepid Offerings, or mining for region-specific resources, unlocking fast travel can make things a lot easier. Even though the Cottage can eat up a big chunk of your resources, it's always worth the investment to make your time more worthwhile in Luma Island .

item.title: Best Indie Games for Beginners
item.description: The indie game scene is the go to place to find creative innovation in games these days. If you're just starting to explore indies, from Five Nights at Freddy's to Hollow Knight these are massive successes that are as good as they are popular.

item.title: 8 Games Where You Can Raise Creatures From Eggs
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Creature collector games can offer diverse gameplay genres, allowing players to raise creatures from eggs to build powerful teams.
  • Games like Monster Crown, Pokemon, and Ark: Survival Evolved involve hatching and raising eggs to form a formidable army of creatures.
  • Unique mechanics in games such as Siralim 2 and Stardew Valley provide players with hours of gameplay tweaking builds and hatching exotic eggs for their farms.

Creature collector games have a long and storied history, but they have always been an inherently engaging and fun pastime. From the monoliths of the genre like Pokemon to the ambitious indie titles putting their own spin on archetypal formulas and mechanics, there's always something to look at and explore with games that let players rear up beasts in some capacity. Being able to raise creatures - tracking and charting their growth from birth onwards - doesn't appear in a lot of games, but when it does, it's usually a treat.

Whether in colony sims, farming sims, or monster tamers, there's a variety of different niches in which players can hope to raise creatures. Whether this is to build a lifelong bond with an animal companion, gain one more pack animal, or make the start of some sort of ravenous beast army, is usually up to player discretion. These games in particular form a diverse range of genres allowing players to raise creatures from eggs onwards, usually to whatever end they see fit.

1 Monster Crown

A Unique Monster-Tamer With Great Aesthetics

Inspired by classic Pokemon games on the original Game Boy and Game Boy Advance, Monster Crown is an incredibly interesting spin on the monster-tamer genre, taking a much more adult approach to the setting and capturing the charm of those early Pokemon designs perfectly.

Creatures can be hatched from eggs in this game, and also form eggs for hatching subsequently after fusion, which makes for an incredibly interesting system of building a team to one's liking from a host of options.

2 Pokemon Scarlet And Violet

A Land Of Whimsy And Vitality

Eggs have been around in almost all of the mainline Pokemon games to date. From the Bad Egg of Emerald , spawning a slew of myths about the game, to the Strange Eggs of Pokemon Go and the droves of adorable level 1 creatures every player loves to see.

Eggs are only hatched by players in Pokemon who carry them while walking around, filling up a slot in their party. One interesting thing to note is that if a Pokemon with the Flame Body ability is at the head of the party, the steps needed to hatch eggs are halved.

3 Ark: Survival Evolved

A Brutal But Rewarding Sci-Fi Survival Game

An often brutal game that asks much of its players, Ark: Survival Evolved has had a long history of servers with brutal clan wars across a host of maps, but one of the main draws of this game is the monster-taming elements.

Creatures can lay eggs which may be fertilized and hatched, giving players generations of creatures like raptors or wyverns to turn into a formidable army or disrupt the natural ecosystem.

4 Monster Hunter Stories 2

Monsties Are Engaging And Creative

A fantastic title for those looking for a monster-tamer JRPG, or for those who want to engage in the Monster Hunter universe but hate the monster-hunting side of things, Monster Hunter Stories 2 is a definitive sequel to a great story-focused game.

Players engage in simple but immersive scissors-paper-rock style battles alongside their monster buddies, affectionately termed "Monsties," and can raise new creatures from eggs found in nests as a slightly unethical means of getting new companions.

5 Stardew Valley

Chickens And Ducks And Dinos

There are a host of eggs available in Stardew Valley , and while some of them are more focused toward being trinkets or accessories, some are actual, proper eggs, that can be incubated and left to hatch.

Chicken eggs are the most common example of this, but there are some rarer eggs available, such as void chicken eggs, or even the huge and ancient dinosaur eggs for those wanting a more exotic farm.

6 Siralim 2

A Hardcore Monster Tamer Roguelike

  • Platform(s) : Windows, macOS
  • Released : August 12, 2016
  • Developer(s) : Thylacine Studios
  • Genre(s) : RPG

A no-holds-barred grindfest of a game, Siralim 2 has some incredibly interesting ideas worked into its foundation. Creatures can be fused and raised from eggs in this brutal monster-tamer roguelike, which has a broad away of stats and modifiers.

This game is perfect for those who want to sink hundreds of hours into tweaking the absolute, inarguable, most fine-tuned builds they possibly can. Each creature can have its stats altered by fusion and items in such a way that they are essentially the players to shape in their image.

7 Palworld

A Chaotic Monster Tamer Shooter

Few games are as chaotic as Palworld . Its aesthetic is chaotic - a Breath of the Wild -style high fantasy world with very Pokemon- esque (maybe a little too Pokemon -esque) designs, photo-realistic guns and equipment, all paired with anime character designs. It's...a lot.

But it also has to be said that there are few things as cathartic as stumbling upon a rare-looking egg in the wild and hatching it to find some new, absolutely bizarre, or terrific Pal to add to one's collection.

8 Rimworld

Creative Animal Breeding Mechanics

Like most of the systems in Rimworld , there is a complex but surprisingly straightforward system for the fertilization of a host of creature eggs. Farming in Rimworld and building up a good stock of animals is a great path to long-term success.

Whether players want to breed chickens or ostriches, if they can get a male and female together, it will eventually happen. Baby creatures are far easier to tame and working with baby animals can be a cathartic break from the horrors that often lie in wait in Rimworld .
